txt: I am between 30 and 55 years old
Tax structures should not exaggerate and amplify inequality
I live in a major city
Excise tax on cigarettes have helped reduce smoking. Similar taxes should be considered for other issues such as pollution, traffic congestion and sugar consumption.
Consideration of the "fairness" of tax needs to include the full tax and transfer system - that is why we have benefits and WFF.
Our monetary system needs to be changed to a Sovereign Monetary system. Govt would then fund the economy & taxes controlling inflation.
Our top tax bracket is 33% from $70,001. Our median income is only a bit more than $20,000 less than that. We need another tax bracket.
Working for families creates middle class beneficiaries and perverse incentives to turn down promotions that would lead to long term gain
NZ’s current tax settings have contributed to growing income, wealth and social inequalities.
Legal tax avoidance by multinationals must be addressed as a matter of priority. This revenue could ensure wealth was paying its fair share.

Business innovation and new technologies mean that workers will be out of work more often and need to retrain. This will reduce revenue from income tax. New ways of supporting these workers will need to be found (e.g. a universal basic income) and paid for.
NZ should re-institute wealth taxes (e.g. death and gift duties) to make the tax system fairer and more progressive.
A tax on wealth (supported by a gift tax) is a fair and reasonable way to tax accumulated wealth.
Reducing waste could generate as much money as increasing taxes - our government is top heavy and over-peopled, let's slim it down.
My household income is above  $100,000 per year but less than or equal to $150,000 per year

Home ownership can boost local communities and social stability. But fewer people live in their own homes, which are increasingly unaffordable. Fixing that is a complex issue…but taxes on wealth are among the policies that need to change.
I am 55 years old or older
A UBI and government spending, funded by government created money, could be used to fund the economy. Taxes would then control inflation.
A broad-based, low-rate system with few exemptions is the best overall approach to tax in New Zealand
I propose Increasing GST to 25-30% and ban all Income Tax and dissolve the IRD as I would become a redundant department
Tax isn’t a weapon politicians use against the economy. It’s what we use to pool our resources and secure the things we need: schools, hospitals, homes and more.
all taxes should be structured to reduce inequality gradually over a decade or two by including wealth in their assessment
Loopholes which allow the wealthy to pass far less tax percentage wise must be closed to ensure a fair and equitable tax system.
I see cheap food in UK, Aus & USA. Gst penalises children & low wage. Food/water/home shouldnt be a luxury item for elites
To enable NZ companies to compete internationally, the company tax rate needs to be reduced so that it is similar to those in countries we trade with.
Too much of our tax take is derived from income and consumption. Owners of capital need to bear a far bigger share than they currently do.
Tax evasion by any means should be seen as a crime against the society.
Since the 1980s the tax system has been used to benefit wealthy interests at the expense of working people
Tax is an issue for all of us. The Tax Working Group written submission process is not sufficiently democratic and they should have designed a comprehensive public engagement process
My household’s income is $50,000 per year or less
All income should be taxed on the same basis, whether from wages, salary, self-employment or capital gain.
You can't lump pollution and sugar togeher but I agree with portions of this argument.
There should be no exemptions to GST as it’s impossible to rationally decide what should and should not be exempt. Exemptions are gamed by companies and are only good for the lawyers.
Taxes need to be simple to understand and transparent
The GST rate should be reduced as GST is a regressive tax that impacts low income families most.
Effective marginal tax rates (EMTR) matter.  The highest EMTRs are for those moving off a benefit.  A tax free threshold would help them.
'Sin taxes' (such as taxes on cigarettes or alcohol) don't significantly change behaviour and mainly punish poor people
My highest qualification is from secondary school
I envision that a flat tax across the board with no exemptions or loop holes on all earnings from any source (say 20%) and a GST
I am prepared to pay a higher tax rate to improve our public services
The GST should be removed from basic foods. It is a regressive tax that hits the poor hardest.
I am either 30 years old or younger
Many of the statements are cannot be answered by simply agree or disagree
No tax exemption for charities.  Services now done by charities eg Refuge would be funded by the tax, & Sanitarium etc would pay fair tax.
Tax the wealthiest 15% significantly more on their wealth. They have benefited most due to poor government policy at the expense if most.
A gradual pollution tax for business to provide funds for cleaning up and to discourage pollution. The more pollution the higher the tax.
in 2013 107 out of 161 high-wealth individuals, declared less $70,000 income. Find people like this & tax them. http://bit.ly/taxavoiders12
The community pays tax to provide the services everyone needs - from each according to their means, to each according to their needs.
Company income tax is only 16% of the total tax take. Changes should be made to increase this, particularly from multi-national companies
Taxes should not be used to change behaviours - consumers should be left to decide what is best for them.
Capital gains tax, if implemented, should only be incurred at the point of sale of property
I live in a town or small city
Australia has a capital gains tax, and very high property prices.  A capital gains tax is unlikely to materially impact property prices.
FLAT TAX SYSTEM 20% If you earn a $1000 a week you are Flat Tax is fairest equitable way. Tax laws 4 companies give too many rebates exempt
Digital technologies should make it possible to efficiently collect taxes even if there are lots of different rates and exemptions.
I own a business
Tourism burdens NZ’s environment & essential infrastructure (roads, sewerage, water, health etc.) Impose an entry tax for all non citizens.
My household income is above  $150,000 per year
I own property
A Tobin tax on financial transactions should be introduced to discourage international speculation, which can wreak havoc with NZ’s exchange rate and economy.
My household income is above $50,000 per year but less than or equal to $100,000 per year
I am self-employed
Apart from Working For Families, changes to the tax system have tended to unfairly favour wealthy people at the expense of low and middle income earners.
People who fall on hard times should have access to basic services in a timely manner. These should be funded by national taxes.
Our income tax is some of the lowest in the OECD and this has lead to under-funding of services needed by low income families.
A very small (1%) tax for every financial transaction (transfer, withdrawal etc) would be fair
I live in a rural area
A living wage prevents large firms from removing as much wealth, as they do, from communities.
Results of cutting the size of Government. Slower growth than other OECD countries, costly services, poverty, and collapsing infrastructure
I'm gay
Capital gains tax should be treated differently for housing, investments or business assets
Ariana
Wealthy individuals and companies have removed money from tax cuts, from our community, rather than re-investing, as Rogernomics promised.
We need more eco-based taxes to encourage better ecologically beneficial behaviours.
Tobacco extortion tax is eroding NZ society in a wide range of area's and contributing to that which inhibits reason.
the tax working group should have included a random selection ordinary citizens not just politicians and experts
Companies should not have loopholes, designed to avoid tax,  get exemptions or rebates. Flat tax 20% completely overall.
Churches must pay tax. Companies like Sanitarium have utilised church exemptions  undermining other businesses and creating inequity
Drivers licences and changes to the are charged fees (govt income) plus gst (more govt income).  This is an abuse of power over citizens.
GST on rates should be set at zero. Either that or the Government pass on to the Councils the GST portion on rates instalments collected.
A land or property tax based on the average increase in property value billed with rates is a far better idea than a capital gains tax.
We should be following countries like Australia and the UK and ensuring multinationals pay their fair share of tax in New Zealand where people are using their services.
A broader tax base is needed to secure sufficient revenue for public services in the face challenges such as climate change, an aging population, changing employment patterns and new technologies.
Low taxes are the only real check on the size of government
Helping communities take responsibility for their issues should mean more funding from taxes being controlled locally instead of centrally.
It is not a lack of tax income that leads to underfunded services, but rather the choices made by government on what are priorities to fund
People without children who are on low incomes should get rebates or income top ups similar to working for families
A wealth tax on savings from already taxed income is unfair and unreasonably punishes / discourages positive economic behaviour
Top tax rates in Australia are over 45%. New Zealand has plenty of room for a tax free bracket on low and higher taxes on high incomes.
Secondary tax rates should be adjusted to reflect total income
We are taxed more than what can be justified. Individuals, families and businesses are best placed to decide how to spend or invest their money
Good quality, accessible public services are the necessary foundations for any well-functioning nation
NZ should reduce tax on income and increase it on wealth and pollution.
NZ Statistics show that after tax and transfers, NZ inequality has not been growing in the last 20 years, unlike other places in the world.
We need to encourage start-ups and self-employment by cutting taxes on new small businesses, increasing them to normal gradually over time.
GST disproportionately affects poor people and inflates prices. It should be removed
Tax is the cost of living in a civilised and functioning society.
Local government / councils should be forced to amalgamate to reduce duplication between small councils and thus reduce rates.
Tax exemptions for low income households should be increased to help overcome inequalities

Local government is already under pressure to deliver many essential services, including local roading, water supplies and flood protection. These pressures are likely to increase with climate change. We're rated enough. Funding for local government needs to be sorted urgently.
Whereas workers pay income tax, the robots / machines that replace them do not. May be there should be a production tax, a VAT on value created
Reduce income tax to 10% flat and increase GST, taxing on consumption is fairer and also taxes under the table and black market economy.
Our tax system should ensure wealth does not become concentrated and warp our society
Successful countries past and present have Government spending at 50 to 60% of GDP. New Zealand is around 30%.
When the minimum wage rises, all benefits that are calculated in line with earnings or limits and clawbacks should also be adjusted
Lower personal PAYE Flat Tax for all income earners. Higher rates for different persons is inequitable & encourages avoidance & dishonesty.
The total tax take needs to increase as public services such as health and education have been underfunded for years.
Clear & concise
NZ’s current tax settings have encouraged property speculation, which has contributed to making housing unaffordable for many New Zealanders.
Tax rate thresholds should be adjustment by inflation each year (as per the UK) to ensure the proportion of tax paid remains the same
implement a Tobin Tax to discourage short term currency speculation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobin_tax
Small businesses hiring beneficiaries should be incentivised through tax
People, the environment, the culture, health and happiness of people is more important than purchase power or corporate interests.
We should lower taxes because this would help improve the economy by boosting spending
Those with more should pay more in tax.  Those with more means those with wealth, not necessarily income - we should consider a wealth tax
There should be a tax-free threshold of $20K. It's an incentive to  work, and cuts the bureaucracy of taxing then giving back in benefits
Government is inefficient and lower taxes would mean more efficient spending by the private sector
Lowering taxes would help create the right incentives for people to invest and work hard. This will improve productivity
Whereas workers pay income tax, the robots / machines that replace them do not. Should there be a production Tax,  a VAT on value created?
Lifting benefit abatement rates would encourage beneficiaries to transition to work and help lift them above the poverty line.
Taxes do not fund government spending
Nothing

The most glaring hole in New Zealand’s tax system, from a fairness point of view, is the failure to tax wealth in any form, except for the government’s very minimal tax on houses sold within two years of purchase.
Government spending used to fund the economy. Taxes would then be a control mechanism for the amount of money in the system.
I am unemployed
We need to introduce a universal basic income for all residents.  Our UBI, NZSuper, works well - make it for all, starting with children.
my savings approximately $6,400.00 which in the year to March 31 2018 paid gross interest of $6.69 had tax deducted $1.08 net interest $5.31
The lack of inheritance and capital gains taxes, in New Zealand, makes for an unfair and badly balanced tax system.
Spending Power in New Zealand is too centralised.  Give local authorities more ability to improve the lives of their communities.
In a fiat money system like ours the government can always 'fund' its programs, no matter how much or little the government taxes.
Installing solar panels and storage batteries on all state house is an imperative.
Clear and concise
Free dental/medical care funded for beneficiaries relying  solely on their benefit for income. Poor  health costs taxpayers dearly.
The government should work much harder to reel in the estimated $2bn of tax fraud each year. http://bit.ly/taxfraud2014
The Tax system should not be used as an excuse to underfund vital public services
Beneficiaries who earn income should have a lesser clawback of their benefits to encourage them to maximise their work opportunities
Cut all taxes except GST.  Don't allow offsets for business. Thisbperhaps would be fairest tax for all.
sGST is strongly regressive(impacts mainly on lower earners)and should be replaced with wealth and financial transaction taxes.
It's clear and concise
We should tax that which causes harm or is otherwise unsustainable for the environment e.g. pollution, use of fossil fuels etc
GST was a simple switch, to make those on low incomes pay more tax, to finance those on high incomes paying less.
Taxes are useful to influence behaviour as well as raising revenue
The tax people pay must fairly reflect the total personal wealth benefits they have - not just the "income" they declare to IRD.
Taxes should be used to prevent inflation and inequality
WWF is a subsidy for employers, who do not pay fair wages.
The tax system should be rebalanced - lower incomes' taxes should be reduced, and taxes on the wealthy increased
Create a directory of foreign owned trusts to prevent the $1.35bn of money laundered in NZ each year http://bit.ly/transparencyNZ
All taxes should be structured so the more you earn the more you pay. No tax should be regressive like GST.
